title: Working for Peace
summary: Buddhist practice notes and teachings - buddhism-books-being-peace

thoughts.content:
# Working for Peace

Compassion is required because we inter-are both both the sea pirate and the
rape victim who who drowns herself in the sea. The communist and capitalist. The
conservative and progressive. We are all the products our society produces. We
are all one and the same and must act as us. And take responsibility and
compassion for for all sentient beings.

---

You have to be woke to save the world. Being aware is the Buddhist version of
being woke. Everything we consume has global consequences and those with the
most power must have the greatest responsibility to make positive changes.

---

Know where you are going before you leave, as to not waste your valuable time.

> We should be aware. The most basic precept of all is to be aware of what we
> do, what we are, each minute. Every other precept will follow from that.

---

A non-dualist mindset requires viewing everything as one and nothing is
separable enough to be juxtaposed against our beings. It means to inter-be.
Indivisible. Whole. Of a piece.

---

Peace can only be achieved through mediation by a truly empathetic person. Being
unable to see that we are truly the same being - we inter-are - means that we
will not being able to bring about peace. We are all mothers and children; we
must remember that when we think of our “enemies” as much as when we think of
those close to us.

---

### 7 Practices of Reconciliation

1. Face-to-face sitting
   - Attempting to reach a meditative calm while sitting in front of the other in conflict is a tough feat indeed.
2. Remembrance
   - Trying to recall all the details of the day/event and see the differences between the stories as told from different perspectives.
3. Non-stubbornness
   - Just like Scanlon’s contractualism, this process requires honest and willing participants to come to the table with an honest desire to reach a resolution.
4. Covering Mud with Straw
   - Loving advocates for both sides of the disagreement speak kind and loving words on each behalf.
5. Voluntary confession
   - Starting small, each party admits to small transgressions in order to prime the resolution pump for higher levels of acceptance.
6. Decision by consensus
   - The entire group/sangha uses consensus decision making to determine the outcome of the dispute.
7. Accepting the verdict
   - Once decided by consensus, the decision is final and must be respected by all parties for the sake of the sangha’s unity. You can’t win all battles.

---

We have to be the peace we want to see in the world. Treat others like peaceful
beings and eventually they will become one.
